descriptionLinks: Calculate Electronic Band Gap via GW Approximation: https://docs.exabyte.io/tutorials/dft/electronic/gw-vasp-bg/
description: We illustrate in this animation how the results for a band gap computation on crystalline silicon can be further improved and made to be more accurate through the use of the GW Approximation.
title: Exabyte.io Tutorial: Band Gap via GW Approximation

youTubeCaptions.text: Band Gap via GW Approximation tutorial.
Create a simulation, by navigating to the job designer page.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> open the workflow tab, and choose the 'D1-GW0-BG' workflow by selecting it in the list.
We now explore the subworkflow structure making up the overall workflow. <break time='5.0' />
Try opening the 'SCF many bands' subworkflow, used to perform a calculation over a large number of unoccupied bands.
Then, open the only unit component, called 'vasp_nscf', and inspect the VASP input files displayed at the bottom of the unit editor interface. <break time='10.0' />
Let us also inspect the contents of the main GW step of the computation, by opening the 'G0W0 step' subworkflow. Again, let us review the VASP input files displayed at the bottom of the unit editor.

After that, <break time='0.5' /> navigate to compute tab, and set compute configuration. Here, we use one node with eight cores on the OR8 queue, due to the significant computational cost of the GW method.
Then, <break time='0.5' /> set the name for the job. Here, we call it - Silicon Band Gap GW Calculation.
Next, <break time='0.5' /> save the job. <break time='3.0' /> It can then be selected and submitted to the compute queue, for execution.
The status of the calculation will, accordingly, change from submitted, to active. Please wait, until the job has finished running. <break time='5.0' />
When the job is finished, open it, to inspect the final results.
The band gap value can be found, at the bottom of the results page. Here, we can see the indirect gap, of about 1.094 eV, in excellent agreement with the experimental value for silicon.
